title: Classic Margherita Pizza
description: Authentic Italian Margherita pizza with fresh mozzarella, San Marzano tomatoes, and fragrant basil. This recipe brings the taste of Naples to your home kitchen with a crispy, chewy crust and perfectly balanced toppings.
shortDescription: Classic Italian pizza with fresh mozzarella and basil
intro: Learn to make authentic Margherita pizza at home with this foolproof recipe. Master the art of Neapolitan pizza making with simple ingredients and traditional techniques.
story: This classic Italian pizza originated in Naples in 1889 when pizza maker Raffaele Esposito created it for Queen Margherita of Italy. The red tomatoes, white mozzarella, and green basil represent the colors of the Italian flag. Today, it remains the gold standard for pizza worldwide.
testimonial: This is hands down the best pizza I've ever made at home! The crust was perfectly crispy on the outside and chewy on the inside. My family couldn't believe I made this myself!
imageAlt: Classic Margherita Pizza with fresh mozzarella and basil

items: 4 cups (500g) all-purpose flour or 00 flour
1½ cups (360ml) warm water (105-110°F)
2¼ teaspoons (7g) active dry yeast
2 teaspoons (10g) salt
2 tablespoons (30ml) extra virgin olive oil
1 teaspoon sugar
1 cup (240ml) crushed San Marzano tomatoes
16 oz (450g) fresh mozzarella cheese, sliced
1 cup fresh basil leaves
4 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil
2 cloves garlic, minced
Salt and black pepper to taste
Parmesan cheese for finishing (optional)

instructions.instruction: In a large bowl, combine warm water, yeast, and sugar. Let sit for 5-10 minutes until foamy.
Add flour, salt, and olive oil to the yeast mixture. Mix until a shaggy dough forms.
Knead the dough on a floured surface for 8-10 minutes until smooth and elastic. The dough should be slightly tacky but not sticky.
Place dough in an oiled bowl, cover with plastic wrap, and let rise in a warm place for 1-2 hours until doubled in size.
Meanwhile, prepare the sauce by mixing crushed tomatoes with minced garlic, a drizzle of olive oil, salt, and pepper. Set aside.
Preheat your oven to 500°F (260°C). If using a pizza stone, place it in the oven during preheating.
Punch down the dough and divide into 4 equal portions. Let rest for 10 minutes.
On a floured surface, stretch or roll one portion of dough into a 10-12 inch circle. Transfer to parchment paper or a pizza peel.
Spread 2-3 tablespoons of tomato sauce over the dough, leaving a 1-inch border for the crust.
Arrange mozzarella slices evenly over the sauce. Don't overload with cheese - less is more for authentic Margherita.
Drizzle with a little olive oil and season with a pinch of salt.
Transfer pizza to the hot oven (or onto the pizza stone) and bake for 10-12 minutes until crust is golden and cheese is bubbling.
Remove from oven and immediately top with fresh basil leaves. Let rest for 2-3 minutes before slicing.
Drizzle with extra virgin olive oil and serve immediately. Repeat with remaining dough portions.

essIngredientGuide.note: Italian 00 flour is finely ground and creates the most authentic crispy-chewy crust. All-purpose flour works as a substitute but won't be quite as tender.
Use whole milk mozzarella (fior di latte) or buffalo mozzarella. Drain well and slice instead of shredding. Pre-shredded mozzarella contains anti-caking agents that prevent proper melting.

These Italian tomatoes have the perfect sweet-tart balance and low moisture content. Look for DOP certification on the can for authentic San Marzano tomatoes from the volcanic soil near Mount Vesuvius.
Always use fresh basil leaves, never dried. Add them after baking to preserve their vibrant color and aromatic oils. Dried basil will taste bitter when baked.
Use high-quality EVOO for drizzling. It adds fruity, peppery notes that complete the flavor profile. The final drizzle after baking is essential.

completeProcess.title: Prepare the Dough
items: Proof the yeast in warm water with sugar for 5-10 minutes
Combine flour, salt, olive oil, and yeast mixture
Knead for 8-10 minutes until smooth and elastic
Place in oiled bowl, cover, and let rise 1-2 hours until doubled
Punch down and divide into 4 equal portions

completeProcess.title: Make the Sauce
items: Crush San Marzano tomatoes by hand or with potato masher
Mix with minced garlic, olive oil, salt, and pepper
Taste and adjust seasoning - it should be slightly tangy
Set aside at room temperature (don't cook the sauce)

completeProcess.title: Prepare Toppings
items: Slice fresh mozzarella into ¼-inch rounds
Pat dry with paper towels to remove excess moisture
Wash and thoroughly dry fresh basil leaves
Have olive oil ready for drizzling

completeProcess.title: Assemble and Bake
items: Preheat oven to 500°F (260°C) with pizza stone inside for 30 minutes
Stretch one dough ball into 10-12 inch circle on parchment
Spread 2-3 tablespoons sauce, leaving 1-inch border
Arrange mozzarella slices evenly, don't overload
Drizzle lightly with olive oil, season with salt
Transfer to hot oven/stone and bake 10-12 minutes
Remove when crust is golden and cheese is bubbling
Add fresh basil leaves immediately
Let rest 2-3 minutes, drizzle with olive oil, slice and serve

items.question: Can I use store-bought pizza dough?
items.answer: Absolutely! Store-bought dough works great and saves time. Let it come to room temperature for 30 minutes before stretching for easier handling and better texture.

items.question: What temperature should my oven be?
items.answer: Heat your oven as hot as it goes, ideally 500-550°F (260-290°C). The higher temperature creates a crispier crust and better browning. A pizza stone preheated for 30 minutes helps achieve pizzeria-style results.

items.question: Can I make the dough ahead of time?
items.answer: Yes! After the first rise, punch down the dough, divide into portions, and refrigerate in oiled containers for up to 3 days. Cold fermentation actually improves flavor. Bring to room temperature 30 minutes before using.

items.question: Why is my pizza soggy?
items.answer: Common causes: too much sauce, wet mozzarella (pat dry first), oven not hot enough, or overloading with toppings. Use sauce sparingly and ensure your oven is fully preheated.

items.question: Can I freeze leftover pizza?
items.answer: Yes! Wrap individual slices in plastic wrap, then aluminum foil. Freeze for up to 2 months. Reheat directly from frozen in a 375°F oven for 10-12 minutes for best results.

items.question: Do I need a pizza stone?
items.answer: Not required but highly recommended! A pizza stone mimics a brick oven and creates a crispier crust. Alternative: use an inverted baking sheet preheated in the oven.

mustKnowTips: Use a pizza stone preheated for at least 30 minutes for the crispiest crust
Don't overload with toppings - authentic Margherita is about balance and simplicity
Let dough come to room temperature before stretching to avoid tearing
Brush the crust edge with olive oil for extra golden, crispy borders
Add basil AFTER baking to keep it vibrant green and aromatic
Use parchment paper for easy transfer to the hot oven
Don't skip the final drizzle of high-quality olive oil - it makes all the difference
professionalSecrets: Add a pinch of sugar to the dough for better browning and subtle sweetness
Let dough rest 10 minutes after dividing before stretching for easier shaping
Par-bake the crust for 3 minutes before adding toppings for extra crispiness
Use a kitchen scale for precise measurements - baking is a science
Stretch dough by hand instead of rolling to preserve air bubbles for better texture
Place mozzarella under AND on top of sauce for restaurant-quality appearance
Finish with flaky sea salt and freshly cracked black pepper
Let pizza rest 2-3 minutes before cutting so cheese sets slightly
serving: Makes 4 personal pizzas (10-12 inches each) - serves 4 people
storage: Store leftover pizza in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 3 days. Reheat in a 375°F oven for 5-7 minutes, or in a skillet over medium heat with a lid for crispy crust. Avoid microwaving as it makes the crust soggy.
allergyInfo: Contains gluten (wheat flour) and dairy (mozzarella cheese). Not suitable for those with gluten intolerance or lactose intolerance. Can be made vegan by substituting with vegan cheese and ensuring dough doesn't contain dairy.
nutritionDisclaimer: Nutritional values are approximate and may vary based on specific ingredients used, portion sizes, and preparation methods. Values calculated for one 10-inch pizza.
notes: A pizza stone is highly recommended but not required. An inverted baking sheet works in a pinch.
00 flour creates the most authentic crust but all-purpose flour is a good substitute.
Fresh basil is essential - don't substitute with dried basil.
Don't skip the final olive oil drizzle - it adds crucial flavor.
The dough can be made up to 3 days ahead and refrigerated.
Leftover sauce freezes well for up to 3 months.
tools: Rolling pin or use hands to stretch
